First reaction: what a great idea!
Second reaction: will anyone actually submit?
Immediate fear: spend time writing something up, only to find out its been canceled
Ive chaired USENIX98, USITS99, and a few other conferences
Most went well but there were some issues
End goal: guidebook (wiki) for program/general chairs
Guide for new program chairs or conference organizers Review management software Best practices
Ideas for new ways to do things How well do rebuttals work? Ratings? Bidding?
Not everyone is a good PC member
Some are too argumentative, dominate the rest of the PC, or have other personality issues
How to find who is a known bad reviewer?
Word of mouth but people tend not to know to ask
How to expand word of mouth?
Always want to bring some new blood into a PC Search for repeat authors who havent served (need a script
to scour Google Scholar for this) Caveat: not everyone knows what to expect and may not be
cut out for it. Dont take too many people you dont know if you can help it
Tips for ensuring the best PC Set expectations early (# reviews, timing, no surprises!)
Have multiple deadlines: force people to miss early rather than all at once just before the decisions
Help with calibration (average scores of reviewers compared to the scores of their peers on same papers)
Avoid inbreeding, or the appearance of it
There are enough people who will have published at an established conference that a chair should draw on them rather than outside the conference community
Rebuttals (Seem to be a nice idea, but add lead time)
Reviewer ratings (hard to calibrate; dont want to insult)
Sponsorship Some institutions make it a pleasure to run a conference, and some
make it much harder Doing it alone has risks (e.g., liability): who owns the conference risks?
Setting expectations Its hard to know just how many submissions a new conference will get:
better to be swamped (and add PC members) than miss all your targets Publicity is amazingly critical (who knew?)
Scheduling Watch for conflicts and hope the others watch too Consider the impact of rejected papers from one conference being
Simultaneous submission seems to be a big problem
We need a better mechanism for detecting
Neutral agent to collect papers and analyze for overlap
Get multiple organizations to buy in
Neutral agent to collect feedback, and if someone gets multiple negative reports, somehow blacklist
